Now that Highlands District 106 is back in school, here are a couple of road safety reminders:

Wolf Road - Please be aware of construction on Wolf Road starting August 19.

Bike Riders - Please be on the look out for bike riders in the morning and afternoon. District 106 is a commuter district with many young bike riders so be alert during these times.

Walkers - A large number of parents and students walk to and from Highlands each weekday. Please pay attention to high traffic areas for school walkers.

Crossing Guards - Please be respectful to our crossing guards in the mornings and afternoons. This important group helps keep everyone safe each school year during rain, snow or sunshine.

Drop Off and Pick Up Locations: Please be patient and use caution when going through the drop off and pick up lines. Life has us all in a big hurry, but slow down and be alert for everyone's safety.

Dear Highlands parents,

I share the following message on behalf of Heather Pilch (Teachers' Union President) and John Corcoran (District 106 Board President):

The start of the school year is rapidly approaching, and we look forward to another great year here at Highlands! At this time, we were hoping to announce a finalized teachers' contract in conjunction with the beginning of the school year. Unfortunately, the Board and Teachers' Union have not yet come to a final agreement. We have utilized the services of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service throughout the negotiation process and have reached tentative agreements on a number of issues. We are now down to the topic of economics (i.e., salaries and benefits). Both parties have been working in good faith with one another and anticipate a resolution soon. We are excited for students' return to school on August 21 and for a great kickoff to the year!

Thank you, and have a nice evening.

post_text: During our 6th grade language arts study of mythology in May, each student chose to research and report on a character from the mythology of an ancient world culture. Students conducted their research using both print and online sources, and then they wrote first-person speech scripts introducing their chosen characters. As a culminating event, students dressed in costume and presented 3 to 5-minute oral presentations IN character to the class and parent visitors. It was truly a privilege and honor to be visited by so many gods, goddesses, heroes -- and even a few monsters -- from Greek and Roman, Norse, Hindu, and Polynesian mythology. Kudos to our students for writing such informative speeches and rehearsing tirelessly so they could present their characters' stories with poise and polish!

post_text: Tim Kogucki and his fellow University of Illinois classmates competed in the Society of Automotive Engineers Formula Race on May 18. The team was ranked 5th in the nation going into the competition and placed 18th in a field of more than 100 teams! Tim is the lead engineer on the suspension subsystem and is a junior majoring in Mechanical Engineering at U of I. Another former Hornet, Joseph Koszut is a sophomore at the University of Illinois, he also studies Mechanical Engineering, is responsible for tuning components with the engine subsystem.
